root.story: TimeLawg - Automatic time tracking for lawyers
root.description: A Windows 11 desktop application that automatically captures window activity for civil litigation lawyers, recording window titles and application names at second-level precision with all data stored locally for attorney-client privilege preservation.

children.description: As a lawyer, I want TimeLawg to automatically capture my computer activity so that I don't have to manually log my time.
As a lawyer, I want TimeLawg to track which application and window I'm working in so that my time is categorized by activity.
As a lawyer, I want TimeLawg to detect when I'm away from my computer so that idle time is not incorrectly billed.
As a lawyer, I want TimeLawg to capture screenshots so that I have visual evidence of my work for billing verification.
As a lawyer, I want screenshots captured at regular intervals so that I have continuous visual documentation.
As a lawyer, I want screenshots captured when I switch windows so that I capture the moment of context change.
As a lawyer, I want duplicate screenshots removed so that storage isn't wasted on identical images.
As a lawyer, I want my tracked time data stored securely and exportable so that I can use it for billing.
As a lawyer, I want all my data stored locally in SQLite so that attorney-client privilege is preserved.
As a lawyer, I want to export my time data to JSON so that it can be processed by external tools for billing categorization.
As a lawyer, I want to understand my time tracking coverage so that I can identify and explain gaps in my records.
As a lawyer, when time is not tracked, I want to know why (was TimeLawg paused, was it not on, was time deleted) so that I can account for gaps in my billing records.
As a lawyer, I want TimeLawg to log when tracking starts, pauses, and stops so that I can see exactly when tracking was active.
As a lawyer, I want deleted time entries archived so that I know what time was removed and when.
As a lawyer, I want to see a report of untracked periods with reasons so that I can explain billing gaps.
As a lawyer, I want TimeLawg to detect if it crashed and record that as a reason for untracked time so that I know gaps weren't intentional.
As a lawyer, I want an unobtrusive interface so that TimeLawg doesn't interrupt my work.
As a lawyer, I want TimeLawg to run in the system tray so that it's always accessible but not intrusive.
As a lawyer, I want TimeLawg to start automatically with Windows so that I never forget to track my time.
As a lawyer, I want to view my captured screenshots and time data so that I can verify what was recorded.
